title: 111_hr3850
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Nutria Eradication and Control Act of 2009". It includes findings and purpose statements. Congress finds that wetland and tidal marshes in the Chesapeake Bay and other coastal States provide cultural, economic, and ecological benefits to the United States. The South American nutria is causing substantial marsh loss in Maryland and Louisiana. The Nutria Eradication and Control Act of 2003 authorized successful eradication efforts in Maryland. The Coastwide Nutria Control Program, authorized by Law 108-16, has significantly reduced nutria-impacted wetland acres in Louisiana. Techniques developed under the Nutria Eradication and Control Act of 2003 are successfully eradicating nutria in Maryland and reducing impacted wetland acres in Louisiana. This Act aims to provide financial assistance to several states for nutria eradication programs. The Coastwide Nutria Control Program, authorized by Law 108-16, has reduced nutria-impacted wetland acres in Louisiana. Maryland, Louisiana, Delaware, Oregon, Virginia, and Washington are carrying out activities to eradicate or control nutria and restore nutria-damaged wetlands. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

Coastal State: Delaware, Oregon, Virginia, Washington.
Program: Nutria eradication program.
Secretary: Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 4. NUTRIA ERADICATION PROGRAM. The nutria eradication program aims to provide financial assistance to Maryland and Louisiana for nutria control and wetland restoration. Goals include eradicating nutria in Maryland, controlling them in Louisiana and coastal states, and restoring damaged wetlands. Activities in Maryland consist of management, research, and public education. According to the document by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, the Federal share of the program's cost cannot exceed 75 percent. Non-Federal contributions can be in the form of materials or services. Administrative expenses are limited to 5 percent of the financial assistance provided by the Secretary. SEC. 5. REPORT. Not later than 180 days after enactment, the Secretary and National Invasive Species Council shall consider reports on nutria in Louisiana and Chesapeake/Delaware Bay watersheds. They will continue a long-term nutria control program with Louisiana and Maryland to reduce damage caused by nutria. The goal is to significantly reduce and restore the damage nutria cause to coastal wetlands in Louisiana and Maryland, and develop long-term nutria control programs with other coastal states. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010 through 2014 includes $4,000,000 for financial assistance to Maryland and Louisiana, and $1,000,000 for coastal states.
